stories.caption: When i first climbed up on the hill, i saw strange scene a mother is climbing up with her son in the thick crowed Rohingya refugee shelter.This woman walked up with her child as I was trying to take a landscape shot, and I could not help but notice how small the baby was. A new chapter in the story of the Rohingya, it shall be, a hope for the future. The streaming flag almost matched the baby’s shirt, as if to exclaim, “here, is where life will start again”.

According to the IOM, the majority of the Rohingya refugees live in Ukhia Upazila, comprising 80% of the total households and individuals. The second largest group lives in Teknaf, comprising 19% of households and 20% of individuals.
Bangladesh government authorities stated that none of the Rohingya would be forcibly returned to Myanmar and that all returns would be voluntary.

Genocide in the Rohingya community in Myanmar's Rokan area last year, which included deep sorrow was no exception for children. Rohingya people have to flee to various countries. one of them was the state of Bangladesh as the largest refuge place which was a temporary destination.

Thousands of makeshift homes in the world's largest refugee camp are captured in these incredible aerial photographs.The array of red, green and white homes, which house more than 1,000,000 refugees who are fleeing terrifying violence, can be seen sprawling for miles in these amazing drone shots.Million of Rohingya refugee are liveing in Kutupalong Rohingya camp near Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh. They made small homes, tent and house for survive their lives.
Rohingya refugee children were playing in the refugee camp all day despite very hot weather

A Rohingya baby mins after being born in one of the temporary refugee camps in Ukhia district of Bangladesh. A Rohingya midwife is providing the medical care, who volunteers at Al-Markazul Islami. There're currently upwards of 2000 pregnancies in the camps and supporting the mothers has been a real challenge for the NGO's. The mother had to be carried to the nearest pregnancy clinic in a blanket tied to a bamboo pole on the shoulders of men of the family just 15 mins after a normal delivery.

when I first set foot in the Cox's Bazaar refugee camp in Bangladesh I saw a mother with two sons and did not feel the tears running down. I immediately said with reflex I took out the camera and captured the moment. this photo for me was very deep because as a humanitarian volunteer I felt welcomed by the strait speech that came with that moment. this photo has become valuable in my life.

"My mother is overjoyed to have a guest travel so far to come visit our home" 20 year old Sadak translates as his mother prepare dinner for us in their temporary shelter. Sadak lives with his mother, sister, aunty, and cousin in Kutupalong refugee camp - both his father and uncle were executed in Myanmar. "She hopes you share our story with the World"

when I became a volunteer, I was assigned to Bangladesh on a humanitarian mission to help Rohingya refugees. one morning I saw a young people of Rohingya youths playing football. they were so happy in a state of deprivation because they were in a refugee camp.

"When hundreds of thousands of terrified Rohingya refugees began flooding onto the beaches and paddy fields of southern Bangladesh in August 2017, it was the children – who made up nearly 60 per cent of their number – who caught many people’s attention," UNICEF said.

Save the Children said, more than half of refugees are children. They made up 52 percent of the refugee population in 2017, up from 41 percent in 2009, according to a study from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).

In October 2017 I became a humanitarian volunteer for the Rohingya community in Bangladesh's Jamtholi Cox's Bazar refugee camp.in this refugee camp I found many things. one of them is Mariyam 86 old who was unable to walk as usual, was forced to be stretched out to go to the field clinic to get health services.The lessons that we can take from that condition are grateful because we are people who can still enjoy a comfortable, safe and adequate life. be grateful and keep peace.

A bamboo and tarpaulin city, the world’s largest refugee camp. The background hills are in Myanmar from where Rohingya people fled horrific violence. The foreground is Bangladesh. This place was recently a forest where elephants roamed, now it’s a safe space for a persecuted people. There is colour and hope here and eyes that brim with love, strength, compassion and pain. You see this in people’s homes, clothes and in landscape itself. But there’s also loss for a natural habitat forever changed.

There were Rohingyas here a month ago(Baruipur, West bengal). Now their camp is completely empty. It is not clear why they are leaving the camp. However, this comes after weeks India deported some Rohingya refugees back to Myanmar. Some people say fear of identification, and someone says there is a problem with the place. A family is still a little away from the camp. The people of the village are renting their homes by raising their subscriptions. There are 18 members in this Rohingya family.

Nurjahan Begum is a rohingya refugee from Mayanmar. Her child suffering with diarrhea for a week and right now her child admitted into Cox's Bazar refugee camp temporary hospital to take treatment. "Rohingya children study in a kindergarten school run inside the refugee camps in Kapan. The students are a trying to get back their childhood in a little sanctuary in the host country. Going to school provides them with a sense of normalcy and a place to process the traumas experienced and it also provides them with the best chance for a fulfilling future."

Rohingya Exodus: Local Bangladeshis distribute food from councils despite being overwhelmed by the sheer number of Rohingya. International aid agencies had yet to fly in and establish operations at this point- just one week after the village raids in Rakhine state, Myanmar, begun.

They are Myanmar's Rohingya community children. Victims of state terrifying oppression Bangladesh has given shelter to them. These children are told to talk about how their parents and mothers killed the government of Myanmar in cold blood. They have Rohingya Kemp in Bangladesh.

Recently I went to stay in a bungalow with friends in Teknaf, an upazila of cox's bazar district in the division of Chittagong. The name of the region comes from the Naf river which flows dividing Bangladesh and Myanmar. The bungalow we stayed was just beside naf river. And the river meets Bay of Bengal 3/4 kilometers from here. Rohingya refugees come to Bangladesh crossing this river.

One year after nearly one million Rohingya families were forced to flee home in search of safety, they now face dangerous flood and landslide conditions at the camps they've sought shelter. Support Rohingya Refugees For Get back to their contry & also support Bangladesh.

Described by the UN as one of the most persecuted minorities in the world, the Rohingya are a group of stateless Muslim people with their own language.

A Rohingya father, with his sick son, during the exodus from Myanmar to Bangladesh. Finally, after more than one year of violence, United Nations said "Top military commanders in Myanmar should be investigated and prosecuted for the “gravest” crimes against civilians under international law, including genocide". In my book "Exodus", published in January and in sale on Amazon.com, I wrote what happen, using the word "genocide".

The humanitarian crisis caused by escalating violence in Myanmar’s Rakhine State is causing suffering on a catastrophic scale. As of 24 May, there are an estimated 905,000 refugees in Cox’s Bazar. Not only has the pace of arrivals since 25 August made this the fastest growing refugee crisis in the world, the concentration of refugees in Cox’s Bazar is now amongst the densest in the world. Refugees arriving in Bangladesh—mostly women and children—are traumatized, and some have arrived with injuri

This young refugee was seen walking on the makeshift dirt road with her books in hand. I was able to take this photo when I went to the Rohingya Refugee camp in Cox's Bazaar, Bangladesh. The girl is the center of this image, and her new home is seen in the acres and acres behind her. Though this may not be a photo with a spectacular scenary, it grabs the reality of the situation in the Rohingya camp this year. Progress is being made, but nothing is like it used to be for these refugees.

Two Rohingya kids playing with the dirt in the slanting afternoon sun in Balukhali refugee camp in Southern Bangladesh. They were so engrossed in their little game of filling up a plastic bottle with earth and then emptying it again that they didn't even notice me as I kneeled near them to take this picture.
They decided to play after a tiring day building their community.
A Rohingya Community in Cox's Bazar. Most of them came from Myanmar, now, this is what they call home

This picture was taken on a late afternoon in Balukhali refugee camp, in Southern Bangladesh. In the backdrop, the rolling hills covered with makeshift tents are visible. Rohingya people have fled their home in Myanmar for Bangladesh since August 2017; the UN declares this situation the "world's fastest growing refugee crisis."

Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh refer to the Rohingya refugees from Myanmar living in Bangladesh.  As of December 2017, an estimated 655,000 to 700,000 Rohingya people have fled to Bangladesh since 25 August 2017, to avoid ethnic and religious persecution by Myanmar's security forces

She gets injured at the same time. Sayed Ullah was the only earning member of Laila's family. Now Laila manage to live with her children a very hard life. Most of her children are below 10 years old.

I just hold the camera and clicked.

I was strolling along the beach when I caught a glimpse of a girl playing with her reflection on the sand, curiously pondering where the beach would end. Little did she know, far beyond that horizon is another world, where more than half a million of Rohingya refugees are living. The scene was so serene it was difficult for me to reconcile the image of this angel, golden dress under the sun, and memories of children who would grow up to know only life in tents, makeshift toys and water puddles.

Shohura Khatun, a Rohingya woman, fled from Myanmar in 1991 during an earlier wave of violence against her people. She is one of the 300,000 registered refugees living mostly in Kutupalong camp. Accompanying her grand-daughter, who arrived from Myanmar just three months ago, for an antennal check-up, she was optimistic about their future: "we have suffered, but we are strong."
A Rohingya boy stands by his shelter on the top of a hill in Jantoli refugee camp, holding his flimsy tarpaulin roof as he watches people below scrambling to prepare for the approaching storm.
Today in Jantoli refugee camp a group of Rohingya men had a discussion about their situation. From behind the tarpaulin their wives paid close attention.

Over 225 Rohingya refugees were rendered homeless due to a massive fire in the early hours of April 15, losing everything to ashes. “I couldn’t save anything. I am left with this torn T-shirt and some borrowed clothes. How will I start everything all over again? Who will help me? I had saved some money and now I am left with nothing,” says Muhammad Ilyas, in broken Hindi, who has been living in India for the past six years.

Kutupalong is the largest refugee camp in the world. It’s located in the south of Bangladesh and inhabits mostly Rohingya Muslims that have fled from the conflict and possible genocide in neighboring Myanmar. The camp is home to more than 550’000 refugees.

LIfe became more miserable for refugees living at the camp as residents of the camp have lost their shelter and all their valuables, including identity cards and special visas issued by the United Nations. Many have also lost documents related to their properties in Myanmar.

The Rohingya in New Delhi have nowhere to go as a major fire tore through their refugee camp in southeast Delhi’s Kalindi Kunj area in the early hours of Sunday, devouring everything in its path.A short-circuit in an electrical wire may have started the fire which then spread to shanties made mostly of asbestos, tin and plastic sheets.

A Rohingya boy who lost all his belongings from a recent fire that tore through the Rohingya refugee camp in southeast Delhi’s Kalindi Kunj area in the early hours of Sunday. No one was seriously hurt, approximately 280 residents lives in the camp and have lost their shelter and all their valuables.

According to the latest UN report, nearly 400,000 Rohingya refugees have crossed over to Bangladesh. The Rohingya people, living in the Rakhine State of Myanmar, are fleeing their homes they have lived in for 200 years. Subject to discrimination for years and not recognised as citizens, the Rohingyas, the majority of whom are Muslims, have for so long been able to eke out a living on agriculture and small farming. With little expectations from the state to guarantee them equal rights.

She arrived at the refugee camp in late August 2017 with her 6 family members. They fled from their home town in Rakhine state by leaving their property, because her father's house was burned by Myanmar's military and they felt imminent danger. In this camp, they receive food distribution onece per 2 - 3 days. Although the living environment is not good, they can live here safely. Recently, She gave birth here, and the number of her family member turned 7.

After Myanmar's army carried out the 'ethnic cleansing' of the Rohingya in Rakhine state. More than half million fled from Myanmar violence including 340,000 children (till october 2017 acoording to UNICEF). During this brutal military crackdown hundreds dead and thousands of villages burned to the ground. After several day's of walk through canal, hill and muddy path a group of women with their child reached safely at refugee camp.

As exhausted they look, these Rohingya refugees flocked to Bangladesh following a mass execution by the Burmese army in Myanmar, August 2017. All of them, including children, had to stand in a queue for 5-6 hours before they receive any relief material because of the huge number of refugees. One fact that hit me the most was they used to get 2 liters of a water bottle for one day that they had to share with other family members. This experience humbled me down to the very core.

A Rohingya refugee boy leads his sister from their freshly built shelters having just recently fled genocide in Myranmar. Behind, the jungle is being cleared to further expand the camp in preparation for the hundreds still arriving each day. The entire hill was populated when we returned a week later.
A Rohingya refugee carries his injured brother through dirty streams to avoid infection. Chopping & collecting wood deep in the jungle, the trek back to camp took us three hours.

Rohingya refugee women wait in line to be seen at at a field clinic setup in Kutupalong refugee camp by the Hope Foundation - a local Bangladeshi NGO focused on providing women with reproductive medical care. With limited access to medical attention and education, women giving birth in their camp shelters result in high maternal women and child mortality rate. Volunteer midwives train and provide services such as field visits, delivery, and postnatal exams.
A young Rohingya girl waits for a food parcel distribution.

As I knelt on the clay floor of this beautiful  Rohingya woman's home,  she shared with me that three of her sons are being held in jail in Myanmar. She does not know if they are dead or alive.  She lost a daughter and two grandchildren at the hands of the Burmese military while fleeing the country.  Now that she has arrived at Kutupalong refugee camp she feels safe from the hands of those who want to take her life,  however is struggling to make her ration card last and fears the coming rains.

Rohingya kids enjoying their moment on the slide with other kids right before the Namaz, on the festive day of Eid. Their families have migrated to India, due to the riots between Burma Buddhists and Rohingya muslims. Their families live in camps, In the capital of the city of India, without any identity and working in small scale industries on daily wages for their basic needs.

In Kutupalong refugee camp no one is immune to pain and suffering. I sat outside this young woman's  home as she shared with me about her journey from Myanmar to Bangladesh and the struggles that her family have encountered upon relocating to the camp.  She asked that I share the story and plight of her people with the rest of the world.

As a nurse and aid worker my primary role is to support the delivery of health care services within Kutupalong camp,  however I have also been given the unique opportunity of collecting the stories of those whom we are serving. This was one such moment.  As I crouched on the floor of Noor Aysha's bamboo hut she began to share her story. It is a story of unfathomable suffering. She gripped my hand  with surprising strength and together we cried, acknowledging and making space for the pain.
The inspiring Indian scholar and feminist critic, Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, speaks on raising a desire for social justice at the Berlin Conference on Myanmar Genocide.

Two men walk the road to old Bagan, I perch on the edge of a 900 year old temple roof and take the photo. Although an up and coming tourist destination in Myanmar, Bagan was also a a resting place for the Indian military as they made their way to Yangon. Their mission was to discuss the Rohingya crisis with the Burmese army, discussions which later led to mass genocide across the borders of Bangladesh. Here however, all is peaceful.

A Rohingya refugee boy flashes a grin as he wades through water with wood he collected to sell at the bazar. He should expect to receive about 1 USD for his day's work.Every day, an endless stream of hundreds of children emerge from the jungle carrying firewood. As wood nearby is collected and the camp increases in population, the children must trek deeper into the jungle. After spending a day trekking with them, we find out they hike a total of 5 hours every day - without shoes or water.

A sick Rohinya child is seen at a makeshift medical clinic for diphtheria - a deadly airborne virus which often result from unsanitary conditions and overcrowding in refugee camps. I shot this as a volunteer photographer for Hope Foundation to promote their organization - a Bangladeshi NGO who provides medical care for underprivileged women, children, and now refugees. Amazing self-funded doctors, nurses, and volunteers come from around the world to give their time making a huge difference.

round 626,000 Rohingya refugees have arrived from Myanmar's Rakhine State in Bangladesh’s south-eastern districts since August, and hundreds more are arriving every day. They join hundreds of thousands who are already living in refugee camps and with local communities.

Man with their cattle’s crossing the Naf river while the rohingya peoples flee from Mayanmar to Bangladesh after massacre done by Arakan army on 11 September 2017 The government of Myanmar, a predominately Buddhist country, claims the Rohingya people are illegal immigrants from neighboring Bangladesh and has denied them citizenship, leaving them stateless.

Novice monks lighting candles before a lounging Buddha statue in the Bagan temple complex of Myanmar. This picture was taken in Kutupalong refugee settlement in Bangladesh which is located several kilometers from the Myanmar (Burma) border. Since 25 August 2017, over 700,000 ethnic Rohingya refugees from Myanmar (Burma) have entered Bangladesh and settled in camps near the border. Along with the existing population, the camp now numbers 900,000-plus making it the largest refugee settlement on earth. This young girl, dressed smartly, is walking back to her "home" on Victory Day, 16 December, which commemorates the prevailing of the allied forces in the Bangladesh Liberation War of 1971. The hills of Myanmar are on the horizon.
Rohingya Muslims child from Myanmar.

Boys and girls are split down the middle in this impromptu classroom, and receive more advanced lessons from those offered to the younger children below. In all, there are about 400-500 students here in Shamlapur, a mix of Rohingya and Bengali.

A young boy in school clothes comes home from madrasa while another comes back from the beach with some fresh fish. There are teachers around that allow Rohingya children to participate in their lessons, privately or at the local mosque, but some families cannot afford to have their children do anything but work.

While the men are on boats at sea or working on neighboring farms, the women stay with the elders and children, drying and tending to their fishing nets. Rohingyas make up an estimated 5,000-7,000 of the 12,000 residents in this fishing village on the coast of Bangladesh.

In order to maintain some idea of home and community, the various blocks in this refugee camp for Rohingyas have organized teams to participate in a football tournament for all to watch. It’s a brief respite from the daily troubles they encounter and an exercise in their solidarity.

Ajida walks through the tightly knit streets of Kutupalong. The shelters are built very close to each other as land is scarce and the camp has a natural necessity to grow at a considerable rate. Mr. Arshadullah, 80 years of age. He is living in Balukhali refugee camp along with his five family members. He is suffering from paralysis and other various aged diseases. A Rohingya baby mins after being born in one of the temporary refugee camps in Ukhia district of Bangladesh. A Rohingya midwife is providing the medical care, who volunteers at Al-Markazul Islami. There're currently upwards of 2000 pregnancies in the camps and supporting the mothers has been a real challenge for the NGO's. The mother had to be carried to the nearest pregnancy clinic in a blanket tied to a bamboo pole on the shoulders of men of the family just 15 mins after a normal delivery.

The Myanmar military conducted innumerable gang rapes of Rohingya women during the years of systematic torture and killings, leading up to the mass exodus which started on Aug 25 2017. This is a portrait of one such victim who agreed to talk on the promise of anonymity. Belonging to an orthodox Muslim community, coming out about these issues is pretty difficult. She said that she had been detained and raped by multiple Myanmar soldiers before she finally managed to flee from Myanmar.

In 2017 Myanmar dominated the headline for the Rohingya crisis in the northern part of the country. Encountering these young women flashing peace signs from a tower overlooking one of the major city centres, ignited a spark of hope that just maybe future generations of all ethnic backgrounds can exist harmoniously with each other.

A Bangladeshi soldier trying to control a mob of noisy Rohingya kids who are waiting for relief. I loved this moment of pure happiness at a place that contains innumerable stories of tragedy, loss and struggles of close to 1 million people without a country.

A Rohingya kid is carrying bricks to help his family build a new home in Kutupalong Refugee Camp in Ukhia, Bangladesh. I stood for a while to observe him. He kept working in the midday heat with a wide smile on his face. It resonated with the general mood of the camp where people consider themselves to be fortunate, even after spending 3 months on limited relief and medical supplies. It was an inspiring example of the resilience of the human spirit.

A small boy uses a large garment as a raincoat during one of the many downpours in the Rohingya refugee camp in Bangladesh. The rain comes quickly and fiercely and offers little reprieve from the heat or the humidity. The rain turns the dirt roads to mud, which makes navigating the camps difficult and dangerous.

A Rohingya man carries his daily ration of food through a rice field, back to his family in the refugee camps in Bangladesh. The main rations are rice, oil and clean water. This man will likely make the same trip again tomorrow, waiting in line for hours and walking through either the scorching sun or the tropical rain.

Rohingya women wait in line for rations at the refugee camp in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh. In the hot, humid tropical season, the line of Rohingya women stretches for almost a kilometre. I managed to make my way to the front of the line while the local military forces commanded the women to sit as they wait for the next food truck to arrive. The women in the queue nodded when I asked if I could take their photos, but their eyes never left the road where the food truck would soon enter.

A young girl wearing Thanakha, a natural sunscreen and makeup made from ground tree bark, stands by a makeshift bamboo fence in a Rohingya refugee camp in Cox's Bazzar, Bangladesh.The girl was watching the men pump for clean water, when I passed her with my 35mm lens. I didn't say a word to her, apart from motioning if it was okay for me to take her photo. She posed for me like this until a got my shot, she then turned around and continued watching the men.

Since the 1970s Rohingya refugees have been coming to Bangladesh from Myanmar. In the 1990s, more than 250,000 resided in refugees camps in Bangladesh. In the early 2000s, all but 20,000 of them were repatriated to Myanmar, some against their will. Most of the refugees are located along the Teknaf-Cox's Bazar highway that is parallel to the Naf River.

The 2017 Rohingya crisis brought over 600,000 refugees into Bangladesh from Myanmar. Young Children, new born babies and women are coming into Bangladesh in thousands every day. The 2017 Rohingya crisis has already brought over 600,000 Rohingya refugees from Myanmar into Bangladesh. Spread across five official camps, the traumatized refugees find solace in little things - being near the loved ones, pursuing daily chores, finding joy in little things.. they are trying to start a new life.

According to the latest UN report, nearly 400,000 Rohingya refugees have crossed over to Bangladesh. The Rohingya people, living in the Rakhine State of Myanmar, are fleeing their homes they have lived in for 200 years. Subject to discrimination for years and not recognised as citizens, the Rohingyas, the majority of whom are Muslims, have for so long been able to eke out a living on agriculture and small farming. With little expectations from the state to guarantee them equal rights.

Aminah Hatu, 65, works on a farm within an Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) camp in Sittwe, Myanmar where the minority Rohingya Muslim community is being (and has been for decades) religiously and ethnically persecuted by the Burmese government. The land is infertile and her farming tools are easily broken, making it hard to farm these lands; however, limited trade and food supply demand the Rohingya people yield as much as possible from the land bestowed upon them.

She doesn’t know her name. When I find her at a dry fish processing zone at Cox Bazar, she was playing. She was playing with a long chain when her parents were working there like bonded labors. Her family had to migrate from Myanmar on gun-point and to save life, had to cross Bay of Bengal to take shelter in neighborhood country. Does this 3 years old girl knows that her life is already chained? Yes, She is a Refugee!

Hussain Ahmad, 38, casually perches himself on the ledge of a small fishing boat while he watches the sun disappear into the sea as it marks the end of another work day. He is a Rohingya man living in an internally displaced persons camp in Sittwe, Myanmar--his people are a religiously and ethnically persecuted minority of the Burmese country. Despite his circumstances, he exudes a captivating sense of dignity and a tangible comfortability with his surroundings and the people he interacts with.

Rashida Hatu, 80, shares a warm moment with her grandson as he flirts with the camera and consequently dissolves the severity of the interview with the flash of his toothy smile. I have traveled to Rakhine State in Myanmar to photo-document the plight of the Rohingya people, especially with regard to women and children. What I have come to learn, time and time again, is that the complexities of social issues rarely define people, rather the human spirit often shines through despite hardship.

A young Rohingya woman listens in on an interview being conducted in an internally displaced persons camp in Sittwe, Myanmar. Chaos surrounds the temporary shelter she resides in, yet the bright light leading into the doorway demands I take notice of her and the serenity inside. Despite the plight of the Rohingya, there is a resilience found within the camp. This woman embodies this strength in her warm and relaxed demeanor as she engages with foreigners and tends to her daily routine.

Chutima Sidasathian is a Thai journalist who helped a team of Reuters journalists gain access to the Muslim Rohingya minority in Southern Thailand. The team of foreign reports received Pulizer for their work: Chutima faced defamation charges and the possibility of 7 years in jail. I met her before she was found Not guilty by the court, so there was still a chance for her to face serious consequences for her activism. One of the bravest young women I've ever met in my life.

A Rohingya refugee woman do hair treatment on March 06, 2016, in Gombak, Malaysia,. Smiles are contagious - even in an IDP camp for displaced Rohingya Sittwe, Myanmar. Behind all the smiles, you would never imagine such suffering and pain. Smiles bring hope, when there is no hope.

I found this girl standing in front of the thatched wall of her permanent shelter in an IDP camp in Western Burma. Her eyes lit up that whole place, a beacon of light in such darkness. I love that children can bring beauty into the most despairing of situations.

I asked this woman if I could photograph her because I thought she was so beautiful. She also reminded me that there is no mercy for the young or the old here among the displaced Rohingya Muslims in Western Burma. If this isn't genocide, I don't know what is.

When Aung Saung Su Kyi's party won a decisive victory in last year's elections in Myanmar, Burmese Muslims and the persecuted Rohingya minority hoped the Nobel prize winner would help to protect them from a growing backlash by the Buddhist majority.The sad fact is, even those who crossed borders generations ago are pressed to leave, and the recent assassination of a prominent Muslim lawyer and politician has everyone on edge, down to laborers who ride the morning circle train.

Bangladesh is already sheltering more than 300,000 Rohingya refugees from Myanmar, there is a view that those countries and organisations which call upon Bangladesh to open the border to Rohingyas on humanitarian considerations may send their planes or passenger boats to Chittagong, and Bangladesh may open the border on the condition that those who come to Bangladesh from Myanmar will be sent to those countries.
